section.title: GêBR infrastructure
section.para: GêBR can take benefit of the resources of multiple machines. To handle it, GêBR is segmented in three layers:

itemizedlist.listitem: The host machine (GêBR-client), from where the user sends requests
An intermediate layer (GêBR-Maestro), where all the jobs are coordinated
Executors (GêBR-Server), where the jobs are executed

section.para: GêBR can be connected to one maestro at once. Each maestro, in turn, can be connected to many Servers. To ease the task of handling of files by the maestro, one requirement is that all the Servers must be in the same Network File System (NFS).

section.title: The Action menu
section.para: From the Actions menu you can access your Preferences and configure Servers. If your enthusiasm for GêBR has lead you to read the whole manual, you have probably used almost all available features found in these options. But just in case, below you will find the documentation for these options.

section.title: Preferences
section.para: The details you provide in the Preferences dialog box will be adopted as the default by GêBR. Specifically:

section.title: Maestro/Servers configuration
section.para:
The Maestro/Servers Interface has three parts:
Maestro - central unit of coordination of multiple machines (for more information, see ).
Servers - choose the servers associated to the current Maestro
Groups of Servers - configure the groups of Servers on the current Maestro
Maestro
Maestro entry

section.title: Servers
section.para: Once selected a coordinator machine (Maestro), the user can associate machines to that Maestro.

The lines represent the machines associated to the Maestro. Each line has two columns: the first column shows if the option Auto-connect is activated or not; the second column shows the name (hostname) of the machine. The user can add a new machine by clicking over New and entering the name of address of the machine.

section.title: Groups
section.para: The user can use just a couple of machines associated to the Maestro. Using different subsets of machines can be managed through the creation of groups of machines.
In the bottom part of the Servers interface, the user can create/edit Servers groups. The user must Drag and Drop the Server to create a group.
To create a group, the user needs to click over a server in the list and drag it to the + icon. A text box is going to be prompted for the name of the group. Groups with same names are not accepted.

section.title: SSH authentication
section.para: GêBR infrastructure comprises communications between machines, namely:
All connections are performed using Secure Shell (SSH) protocol. SSH is intended to provide secure encrypted commnication over a network.

The SSH public key authentication is based on public-key cryptography, where encrypton and decrypton use public/private key pair for authentication purposes. The Maestro knows the public key and only the Client knows the associated private key.

If you choose GêBR to user public-key authentication by checking "Use encryption key to automatically authenticate the next session", then GêBR will create (if not existent) a private/public keys pair and will keep the private key and will copy the public key to the Maestro. Once this operation is successfully done, your authentication on your Maestro will be automatically done through public-key . In practical terms it means you will not need to write your password anymore to connect to that Maestro through GêBR. Analogous behaviour occurs in the connection between GêBR-Maestro and GêBR-Server.

mediaobject.caption: GêBR public-key authentication. Suppose a client wants to stablish a connection. The client is requested for a login credential where he provides the key associated to the Maestro. The Maestro try to match the client key and one of his own public keys. In positive case, the client is allowed to communicate to that Maestro. Otherwise, he is requested for a password.

section.para: Alternatively, you can create the private/public keys pair by yourself (consult here for more information).

section.title: Support to MPI programs
section.para: The Message Passing Interface Standard (MPI) is a vendor independent standard library of message passing. The MPI Forum, which includes vendors, researchers, software library developers, and users, apply efforts to establish the the standards. The goal is to establish a portable and flexible standard for message passing programming. The design of MPI tries to match portability, efficiency, and flexibility. Nowadays, it is a widely used standard for writing message passing programs on high performance computers.

There are many implementations (flavors) of MPI, but the most widely used are OpenMPI and MPICH2. OpenMPI is an open source implementation and has influence of three earlier approaches: FT-MPI, LA-MPI and LAM/MPI. The MPICH2 is another widely used implementation and is based on the MPI-2.2 standard.

GêBR supports both OpenMPI and MPICH2. However, MPI programs can only run on servers that support the execution of MPI. Thus, for GêBR support of MPI, the user must have acces to servers/clusters that also support it.

In the Server Interface, in the MPI column, an icon indicates that the server of that row supports MPI. Roll over the icon to check the flavors of MPI available on that machine. You will be able to run your program just on machines that support the same flavor as the one used on your program.

mediaobject.caption: The second column indicates the types (flavors) of MPI available in your servers.

section.para: To run an MPI program, you must first create a menu in DêBR and choose appropriately the MPI implementation used on your program. Then import it in GêBR. In the Flow Editor tab, if you double-click over the MPI program, you will be able to set the number of processes to be used by that MPI call.

mediaobject.caption: Double clicking over an MPI program you can set the np parameter of MPI.

section.title: The execution log
section.para: GêBR remembers most of the users actions, as well as the results of these actions, in the execution log. This log is shown at the bottom of the main window, which can be presented in the collapsed form (default) or the expanded form like the window below.

mediaobject.caption: At the bottom of GêBR's main window you will find the execution log, which displays information on all of GêBR processes.

tip.para:
In
Actions Preferences at the bottom of the dialog box, we can see the box Load past-execution log. By checking this box we choose to exhibit the whole log, including actions from past dates. By leaving the box unchecked we choose to have a compact log, which only shows actions that have taken place since GêBR's last initialization.
